chapter.title: Titles
chapter.para: Title styles differ depending on where they are used. To avoid typos, consider using entities, such as &sa;, for section names that are frequently used. To be consistent, leave out trailing colons within titles if they cannot be inserted systematically.

section.title: Book
section.para: For a book, use a title that provides enough context. For example, &title-isg; clarifies that the style guide is about documentation rather than a programming language, and &ib; specifies that it is derived from &ib; rather than another entity.

section.title: Chapter or section
section.para: For a chapter or section, use a title that provides enough context without being redundant. In a chapter titled Lists, for example, use section titles Ordered and Unordered rather than Ordered list and Unordered list.

section.title: Procedure
section.para: For a procedure, use a title that starts with a gerund (also known as a verb with an -ing ending), such as Writing in the example that follows. Doing so keeps the procedure name short, and distinguishes the name of a procedure from its steps that start with action verbs.

procedure.title: Writing a procedure
procedure.para: If there are any prerequisites, list them here or provide a link to additional information.

step.para: Create a new file (File â†’ New...).
Write an action verb at the start of each instruction.
For a list of action words, see Bloom's taxonomy.
Name the file similar to that of the procedure.
For example, this procedure's file name could be writing-a-procedure.xml.
Separate any additional information from the main instruction.
For example, previous steps and this one each contain an additional sentence that is not on the same line as the instruction.
